body.p: Every object in the Smalltalk environment is an instance of a particular class. Classes define the form and behavior of their instances (i.e., the messages to which they respond). The behavior is embodied in a set of methods associated with the class. That is, data in Smalltalk generally belongs to instances, while behavior always belongs to classes. Still, classes can also maintain their own variables, such as constants that are available to all of their instances.
Class names may contain numbers, but they must always begin with a capital letter. By convention, camel case is used to name classes.

To browse only the classes in the same branch of the class hierarchy (with a Class Hierarchy Browser), use <Operate> in the classes view and select Spawn Hierarchy.
classesview hierarchyWhen one class is selected in the System Browser, select the Class tab in the navigator to view its hierarchy (it may be necessary to deselect a protocol in order to see this.)
To open a separate Hierarchy Browser, select Class → Spawn Hierarchy.
classesbrowse referencesSelect a class, then select References on the Class menu. A new browser will open showing a list of all methods in the system that directly reference the selected class.

classesfind by nameEnter the class name into the input field in the upper-right corner of the Browser. You may enter the beginning of a class name, or use the wildcard character "*" to narrow your search. Enter <Return> to perform the find.

classestypesWhen creating a new class, you generally choose from one of three available types presented in the class creation dialog (#ephemeron and #weak are rarely used for special purposes only):#none (The most common type) A class with zero or more named instance variables (possibly inherited) and no indexed variables (e.g., True, Point). Can have any kind of subclass. #objects A class of indexable object with zero or more named instance variables and whose indexed variables hold arbitrary objects (e.g., Array, OrderedCollection). Subclasses can only be type #objects, because subclasses must also be object-indexable. #bytes A class of byte indexable object with no named instance variables and whose indexed variables hold only byte objects (e.g., ByteString). Indexed variable contents are accessed by the at: and at:put: methods defined in the class, providing one and two-byte character strings, byte and word arrays, etc. A #bytes class can only inherit from a chain of #none classes with no named instance variables. Subclasses must also be #bytes classes.

classescreate subclassA class name can contain letters, numbers and underscores, but cannot begin with a number. Class names must begin with a capital letter.
In the System Browser, select the package in which to place the new class.
On the Class menu, select New → Class.
Fill in options in the Class Creation dialog, specifying the class name and any instance variable names.
To change class type, or to specify class instance variables or imports, complete fields on the Advanced tab.
Click OK to create the class.

classescreate a collection subclassCollections can point to their elements in different ways. Select either of these options in the Indexed type filed on the Advanced tab of the class creation dialog:

li.p: #objects, for a class that holds a collection of indexable variables, each of which is a pointer to any kind of object.
#bytes, for a class that holds a collection of indexable variables, each of which is a pointer to a byte object.
